snippet: Gov. Chris Christie has approved a record $1.57 billion for dozens of New Jersey’s largest companies after they pledged to add jobs, but critics say the tax breaks are ineffective.
abstract: New Jersey Gov Chris Christie, since taking office in 2010, has approved a record $1.57 billion in state tax breaks for dozens of New Jersey’s largest companies after they pledged to add jobs; he says these are prudent measures intended to help heal the state's economy, but subsidies are criticized by government-reform groups, New York City Mayor Michael R Bloomberg and some New Jersey landlords, who contend that the programs are an expensive and ineffective form of assistance to wealthy corporations.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie has approved a record $1.57 billion for dozens of New Jersey’s largest companies after they pledged to add jobs, but critics say the tax breaks are ineffective.

headline.seo: Christie Gives New Jersey Firms Tax Breaks for Short Moves
headline.main: Christie Leaning on Tax Subsidies in Hunt for Jobs
headline.print_headline: Christie Leaning On Tax Subsidies In Hunt for Jobs
